text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

While the directions presented in this manual are primarily intended for Indian Tribal Governments employees, the information presented concerning interactions with tribes provides guidance for all IRS employees. All IRS employees are required to contact the office of ITG before making initial contact on Indian tribal government cases.
MATERIAL CHANGES

new text, reissues existing information, and reﬂects editorial and/or numbering the subsections. Checked and corrected (where necessary) web addresses, IRM and resources. Signiﬁcant changes to this IRM are listed in the table below:

This revision supersedes IRM 4.86.1, Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) Procedures, Indian Tribal Governments Administration and Policy, dated November 5, 2018.
Tax Exempt and Government Entities Government Entities Indian Tribal Governments
Director, Exempt Organizations and Government Entities Tax Exempt and Government Entities
Governments Administration and Policy
page (
) Purpose. This section introduces the mission and procedures for Indian Governments administration within the office of Indian Tribal Governments. (
) Audience. ITG employees and IRS employees interacting with federally nized Indian tribes. (
) Policy Owner. Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TE/GE). (
) Program Owner. The Program Manager, Indian Tribal Governments, under TE/GE is responsible for overseeing federal tax administration as it applies Indian Tribal Governments. (
) Contact Information. To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, email the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM. (
) The IRS established the Indian Tribal Governments’ function in
under TE/GE Division to serve as the primary contact in the IRS for federally nized Indian tribes. In May
, the TE/GE Division reorganized and combined the Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) and Tax Exempt Bonds (TEB) functions. In November

, the TE/GE Division reorganized creating a separate function for the Office of Indian Tribal Governments. The scope and mission of ITG remains the same, to assist Indian tribes address their tax matters. (

) ITG provides a single point of contact for assistance and tax help. ITG uses partnership opportunities with Indian tribal governments, tribal associations, and other federal agencies to respectfully and cooperatively meet the needs both governments and to simplify the tax administration process. All IRS employees are required to contact the office of Indian Tribal Govern- ments before making initial contact on Indian tribal government cases. (
) This is the sixth revision of IRM
, Indian Tribal Governments tion and Policy. (

) ITG combines compliance and enforcement initiatives with outreach and cational activities to accomplish its goals. The processes and procedures provided in this IRM are consistent with the objectives and goals for ITG. to IRM
, Organization and Staffing, Tax Exempt and Government Division. (

) The ITG Program Manager reports to the Director, Government Entities, Tax Exempt and Government Entities and is responsible for maintaining a func- tional and interactive government-to-government relationship between the and Indian tribal governments as directed by the President’s Executive (see Executive Order No.
FR
, Nov.
) ITG is comprised of three ﬁeld operations groups and a technical group, all reporting to the ITG Program Manager. (
) ITG employees must be familiar with and act according to the Taxpayer Bill Rights. Every employee must consider these rights in carrying out their See IRC
). The IRS formally adopted a Taxpayer Bill of Rights in June
, which provides the nation’s taxpayers with a better of their rights and helps reinforce the fairness of the tax system. IRS Internal Revenue Manual
Tribal Governments Administration and Policy 4.86.1 page
Purpose. This section introduces the mission and procedures for Indian Tribal Governments administration within the office of Indian Tribal Governments.
4.86 Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) Procedures

employees must be informed about taxpayer rights and be conscientious in the performance of their duties to honor, respect and effectively communicate those rights which may aid in improving the taxpayer’s experience. See Pub 1, Your Rights As A Taxpayer, for more information.
IRS employees working tax related matters must identify themselves (The Re- structuring and Reform Act of 1998 (RRA 98) Section 3705(a)).

Tribal Governments Administration and Policy 4.86.1

ITG provides Indian tribal government customers top quality service by them understand and comply with applicable tax laws, and to protect interest by applying the tax law with integrity and fairness. The ITG guided by principles of respect for Indian tribal self
government and eignty. ITG supports a functional and interactive government
to

government ship with Indian tribal governments as directed by Presidential Orders and was established to help Indian tribes with their federal tax Indian tribal governments and tribal associations gave valuable input design of ITG, which focuses on offering a single point of contact for tax Field groups include specialists trained in ITG protocol. Specialists are vised by group managers. Specialists address issues and provide guidance unique to Indian tribes maintain proper protocol with sovereign tribal governments, including and abusive schemes. The IRS is governed by consultation policies that may be adopted by partment of the Treasury. ITG continues this dialogue to ensure we evolve to reﬂect tribal, IRS, and stakeholder needs. The Treasury Department has a consultation process to dialogue with tribes on a government
to

government basis. This allows better and response to their needs on Treasury regulations, legislative proposed legislation and policy statements that have Tribal implications, impacts Tribal economy or preempt Tribal law. The Treasury Office of the Assistant Secretary for Management & Budget is coordinating consultation between the Indian tribes and Treasury bureaus and offices. Please use the e
mail below to contact the official point of contact for tribal consultation if you have any questions,
4.86 Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) Procedures
Contact Information:
Email: Tribal.Consult@treasury.gov
Website: www.treasury.gov/resource-center/economic-policy/ tribal-policy/Pages/Tribal-Policy.aspx

ITG is responsible for any federal tax issues involving federally recognized Indian tribes. ITG provides services and federal tax information to assist in understanding and meeting their federal tax responsibilities. Specialists address unique Indian tribal issues, including: • Employment Tax • Wagering Excise Tax • Occupational Tax on Wagering • Information Reporting • Voluntary Tip Agreements and Annual Tip Reporting • Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) (Title
) ITG is responsible for identifying entities subject to the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) (Title
) that are owned by Indian tribal governments. ITG also is re- sponsible for education and outreach on BSA requirements to entities by Indian tribal governments. See IRM

) for MOU Summary. The office of ITG will provide assistance throughout Indian country as a. Taxpayers may request assistance after receiving a letter, notice or contact between the IRS and a tribal entity. For example, penalties, requirements, deposit due dates, and information return reporting, cor- recting a reporting problem or error. b. With managerial approval, a specialist may proactively offer a tribal entity when the need is identiﬁed. c. Outreach contacts may identify additional opportunities for ITG assistance. The objective of this individualized assistance is to increase voluntary ance by helping our customers to understand, implement and fulﬁll their responsibilities. Help may be by phone, correspondence, email, fax, or face. Individual help is distinguished from outreach by its focus on one issue, rather than general information to a group. If the customer is having difficulty resolving a tax situation, consider whether the situation meets Taxpayer Advocate criteria. See IRM
, Taxpayer

ITG is responsible for any federal tax issues involving federally recognized Indian tribes. ITG provides services and federal tax information to assist tribes in understanding and meeting their federal tax responsibilities. Specialists address unique Indian tribal issues, including:

a. Taxpayers may request assistance after receiving a letter, notice or other contact between the IRS and a tribal entity. For example, penalties, ﬁling requirements, deposit due dates, and information return reporting, cor

recting a reporting problem or error. b. With managerial approval, a specialist may proactively offer assistance to a tribal entity when the need is identiﬁed. c. Outreach contacts may identify additional opportunities for ITG customer assistance. The objective of this individualized assistance is to increase voluntary compli
Note: Individual help is distinguished from outreach by its focus on one taxpayer’s issue, rather than general information to a group.
Tribal Governments Administration and Policy 4.86.1

) A BSA compliance check is a review conducted by IRS, under Title

of Internal Revenue Code and is a tool to educate tribal entities about their Checks reporting requirements and increase voluntary compliance. A BSA check doesn’t directly relate to determining a tax liability for any particular period. As such, ITG specialists don’t review an entity’s books and records during a BSA compliance check. A specialized questionnaire is to be used ITG specialists in conducting the BSA compliance check, which is located in the RCCMS forms repository. (
) A BSA compliance check isn’t: a. An audit or an investigation under section IRC
(b). b. An audit under section
of the Revenue Act of
, as amended. Note: The customer may legally choose not to participate. (

ITG works with Indian tribes to: • Solicit initial voluntary tip agreements • Refresh existing tip agreements • Address tip addendum(s), per customer request • Answer questions on current agreements • Address tip reporting requirements for the employer and the (

) As part of administering federal taxes involving federally recognized Indian tribes, ITG conducts audits to determine compliance with federal tax of Returns and ﬁling requirements. Combined with outreach, education and compliance checks, audits support a balanced approach to improving compliance. (
) ITG has audit authority under IRC
(a), which authorizes the IRS to books and records necessary to determine federal tax liabilities. (
) All audits are in accordance with Policy Statement
, Fairness and Integrity in Enforcement Selection. See IRM
, Policy Statement
, Fairness and Integrity in Enforcement Selection.

) ITG specialists work on issues/cases where tax schemes or abuses have impact across multiple ﬁeld group areas, or involve extensive interactions enforcement functions/agencies inside and outside the IRS. The objective stem the growth of these types of activities through a coordinated national strategy that combines partnerships with customers and other regulatory agencies. (
) Issues include tax fraud, tax shelter activities, Title
abuses, and the use tribal entities to avoid proper reporting and oversight of transactions. (
) Cases are assigned to ITG specialists based on the potential to be the Criminal Investigation (CI) Division, or where the abusive issue(s) may affect other Indian tribes. (

Tribal Governments Administration and Policy 4.86.1

MOU with SB/SE: MOU states Specialty Examination Excise Tax ITG, formerly known as ITG/TEB: Program, formerly known as • Is responsible for all Office of Excise Taxes (OET) wagering tax issues related to Indian tribal govern- ments, including any subdivision, subsidiary, or wholly owned business of the Indian tribal govern- ment. • Is the single point of contact to authorize or to make contacts with Indian tribal governments. • Will refer any issues they identify concerning non- wagering excise taxes to an Excise Tax specialist using the Specialist Refer- ral System (SRS). • Will coordinate education and outreach sessions with the applicable Excise tax group and Indian tribal gov- ernments where potential non-wagering excise tax responsibilities may exist. • Will contact appropriate Excise Issue Specialists (EIS) for assistance to an- swer speciﬁc excise tax questions that do not in- volve wagering. Specialty Examination Excise Tax Program: • Has jurisdiction over all other excise tax issues re- lating to Indian tribal governments. • Will coordinate with ITG before they initiate any ex- amination or outreach ac- tivity with an Indian tribal government, including any subdivision, subsidiary, or wholly owned business of the Indian tribal government.
4.86 Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) Procedures

MOU with SB/SE: MOU states Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) Program ITG, formerly known as ITG/TEB and BSA share responsibilities for BSA and IRC 6050I notiﬁcation and education activities for entities owned by Indian tribal governments.
Note: Find the MOUs at: governments/itg-memorandum-of-understanding/.

Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) (

) On all ITG closed cases that are unagreed and considered by the IRS’s Office of Appeals, the Appeals office will provide an Appeals Case Memorandum (ACM) to the ITG Program Manager, who then sends the ACM to the group manager with supervisory authority for the particular case. The group may provide the ACM to the ﬁeld specialist previously assigned to the case. The ACM is usually Appeals’ only feedback vehicle. (

) Appeals may send feedback in a separate memorandum if they determine some aspect of a closed case warrants special attention in addition to the ACM. Favorable comments by memoranda are encouraged. (
) Appeals may return cases for ITG to verify new information or further ment using an explanatory memorandum. (

) Use Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) command code INOLES to identify an Indian tribal government/enterprise(s) by these codes: • Business Operating Division (BOD) Client • Client code (CC) • Employment code (EC)
for (

) Entities wholly owned by Indian tribes are under the jurisdiction of Tax Exempt and Government Entities/Indian Tribal Governments. Tribes may be involved businesses/enterprises that aren’t wholly owned, such as partnerships and ventures with other tribes or non-tribal entities. The IRS BOD with jurisdiction (TE/GE, SB/SE or Large Business & International (LB&I)) is generally deter- mined by the level of ownership.
Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) Procedures
Use Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) command code INOLES to identify an Indian tribal government/enterprise(s) by these codes:
Example: If an Indian tribal government owns more than 50 percent of a partner- ship, then the entity is coded as TE/GE who may need to coordinate with other BODs.

) If the BOD classiﬁcation is unclear, then these situations will be resolved at lowest managerial levels in the IRS units involved. If the group manager(s) can’t agree, the issue is raised to the next level of management until (
) ITG entities are identiﬁed on IDRS by BOD code “TE”, employment code “I” and client code “I”. (
) If an ITG entity has issued a tax-exempt bond, the CC could be a “
” instead of an “I”. (
) If an ITG entity was at one time exempt under IRC
(c), the EO section show at the bottom of the INOLES display. This EO section is for historical purposes. If the EO status code (STS-CD) is active, this means the entity’s IRC

(c) exempt status is still in effect, subject to EO oversight and not an ITG entity. If the EO status code is inactive, this means the EO tax exempt status is no longer in effect, and it’s an ITG entity if an Indian tribal govern- ment(s) owns more than
percent. See Document
, IRS Processing Codes and Information, Section
), Status Codes - Master Files and AIMS, for a list of active and inactive status codes. (
) Verify the Employer’s Annual Federal Unemployment (FUTA) Tax Return, requirement (FR) on INOLES is correct. The FR for ITG entities is either “
” (compliant - not required to ﬁle) or “
” (non-compliant - required to ﬁle). Most
Administration and Policy
page the time, the Form
FR is “
” indicating that the organization has elected not to be subject to Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) by participating the state unemployment system. (

) Specialists must ensure the Indian tribal governments and related enterprises’ BOD code is accurate. If the BOD, CC, EC and FR aren’t update the necessary changes using the Tribal/Entity Information Update Form. After completing the form, click on the SUBMIT button to send to for input. (
) The Tribal Social Security Fairness Act of
, Public Law
, law on September
This new law amends the Social Security Act creating Section

A to allow voluntary Social Security coverage for recognized Indian Tribal council members. These tribes may also request roactive coverage for past periods when the tribe paid FICA (Federal Contributions Act) taxes but did not request a refund of those taxes from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). For more information, see www.ssa.gov/ people/aian/. (

) The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) has a link to the Federal Register, which publishes the current list of federally-recognized tribes, and Alaskan Native entities. In addition, the BIA maintains a Tribal Leaders Directory on its website. The Tribal Leaders Directory is published semi-annually and lists a tribe’s name, address, telephone and fax number (and email or website, if provided) for each federally recognized tribe. The directory also gives tion on the BIA regions and agency offices. The BIA website is www.bia.gov. (

) The National Indian Gaming Commission (NIGC) was established within the Department of the Interior to implement the provisions of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (IGRA). The Commission has ﬁeld representatives who maintain contact with those tribes that have gaming operations. These sentatives are a useful source of information. The website address is www. nigc.gov. Find the MOU between ITG and NIGC. (
) The Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (Fi
EN) is a bureau of the Department of the Treasury. The mission of the Fi

EN is to safeguard the ﬁnancial system from illicit use and combat money laundering and promote national security through the collection, analysis, and dissemination of intelligence and strategic use of ﬁnancial authorities. Fi

EN carries out its mission by receiving and maintaining ﬁnancial transactions data; analyzing disseminating that data for law enforcement purposes; and building global operation with counterpart organizations in other countries and with international bodies. The website address is www.ﬁncen.gov. (
) USA.gov provides information and services of all federal governmental agencies. Find information about tribal governments and Native American current affairs at www.usa.gov/tribes. (

) The U.S. Government has a unique legal relationship with Indian tribal ments in the Constitution of the United States, treaties, statutes and court decisions. Congress may limit the authority of Indian tribes, but within those limits the tribes retain “attributes of sovereignty over both their members their territory,” U.S. vs. Mazurie,
U.S.
) Tribal government powers include the authority to: Internal Revenue Manual
Tribal Governments Administration and Policy 4.86.1 page
(06-16-2020) Other Federal Agencies Impacting Indian Tribal Governments
Tribal government powers include the authority to:
Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) Procedures

• Establish, within tribal boundaries, the form of the tribal government. • Regulate tribal and individual property. • Determine tribal membership. • Levy taxes. • Establish courts. • Maintain law and order. (
) Generally, Indian tribes provide governmental services, such as education and medical care to Indian tribal members. (

) Although Congress can limit tribal powers of sovereignty, the states can’t. general rule in Indian law is that unless there’s speciﬁc delegation of provided by Congress, state laws generally don’t apply to Indians on tribal land. So, Indian tribes are semi-sovereign entities, or distinct, independent political communities within the borders of the states in which they reside. Their sovereign powers can be limited or deﬁned by an act of Congress or, some cases, those powers may have been implicitly lost when tribes became subject to the overriding U.S. sovereignty. On the other hand, the laws of any state are limited in the ways they can have any direct effect on Indians residing on tribal land, or on the exercise of tribal sovereign power within boundaries. (
) Tribal sovereignty is the foundation upon which the relationship stands. Sovereignty is neither granted by, nor negated by federal statutes, acts or treaties. It is inherent. (
) Over the years, Presidential Executive Orders (see Executive Order No.
FR
, Nov.

) have directed federal government agencies, to the extent permitted by law, to: • Respect Indian tribal self-government and sovereignty. • Honor tribal treaty and other rights. • Strive to meet the responsibilities that arise from the unique legal rela- tionship between the Federal Government and Indian tribal governments. Note: This relationship isn’t intended to prevent IRS from carrying out official government business. (

) A government-to-government relationship is a bilateral recognition of the re- spective parties’ sovereignty. The IRS must interact in a way that respects for Effective tribe’s position as a sovereign entity. ) All ITG employees must be cautious not to damage the relationship of that we have for Indian self-government and sovereignty. This is further in the ITG mission statement, “The ITG office is guided by principles of for Indian tribal self-government and sovereignty.” This relationship can be complex at times given our responsibility to administer the tax laws in a manner to all. It’s very important that the employee knows who the tribe designated to discuss conﬁdential information with the IRS. (
) In addition to the guidelines for Disclosure of Official Information in IRM the following are some speciﬁcs as to how these guidelines may be with regard to Indian tribal governments. (

) As with federal, state and local governments, returns and return a tribal government may be disclosed to any person legally authorized to for such government. Generally, veriﬁcation that the requester is a official, such as Treasurer or Comptroller, will be sufficient to indicate ment to returns and return information. (
) Requests for returns must be made in writing on appropriate governmental terhead. (
) Requests for return information may be verbal or in writing under the lines in Background, IRM
, General Requirements for Disclosure Designee of Taxpayer.

All ITG employees must be cautious not to damage the relationship of respect that we have for Indian self-government and sovereignty. This is further stated in the ITG mission statement, “The ITG office is guided by principles of respect for Indian tribal self-government and sovereignty.” This relationship can be very complex at times given our responsibility to administer the tax laws in a fair manner to all. It’s very important that the employee knows who the tribe has designated to discuss conﬁdential information with the IRS.
Indian Tribal Governments (ITG) Procedures

) If the tribe, in a resolution of the tribal council or other exercise of its powers as a sovereign government, duly designates in accordance with regulatory re- quirements an individual or individuals as the primary point of contact for the IRS, ITG will honor that designation and contacts should be made through individual. The designation may be made with regard to speciﬁc matters or on an on-going basis. (

) If the tribe’s designated representative, or responsible official is an outside attorney, certiﬁed public accountant (CPA), or other professional who is not a tribal official or employee, the rules governing Conference and Practice as codiﬁed in
CFR
to
and explained in the following publica- tions will apply: • Publication
, Conference and Practice Requirements • Publication
, Practice Before the IRS and Power of Attorney Secure Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative. form allows qualiﬁed individuals to represent the tribe in tax matters and to discuss all aspects of an examination or other IRS action. (

) When the specialist has an on-going relationship with the tribe and is familiar with the official responsible for a particular matter, on-going contacts should made with that official (provided that official has been duly designated by the tribe to receive returns and return information of that matter, or is otherwise authorized to receive returns and return information of the tribe because he/ she is a tribal government official legally authorized to act for the tribe). (

) When there is any doubt as to the responsible official, the following steps should be followed: a. Contact the local Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA). The BIA Area Office be contacted to assist in identifying the recognized tribal leadership and the location of the tribal offices. The IRS employee should not advise BIA of the purpose of the inquiry. b. Inquiries should be made to the recognized leaders as to the official(s) with regard to a particular matter. c. If the contact is in regard to a speciﬁc return and the signer of the return can be identiﬁed, that person will be treated as the responsible official provided the individual is still acting in the same capacity as when the return was signed and ﬁled. d. If any doubts remain as to whom the responsible official is or who is entitled to return information, written instructions from the tribal govern- ment should be requested. (

) A tribe may have several entities with separate accounting staffs. There may be a different responsible official for each of these entities. Example: A tribe may have the tribal government office, a housing authority, a health clinic, a casino, and a smoke shop. (

26 CFR 301.6103(c)-1(c)(2) authorizes the IRS to accept a taxpayer’s verbal consent to disclose returns or return information to parties helping the taxpayer resolve a federal tax matter provided that the IRS has:
Governments Administration and Policy

a. Obtained from the taxpayer sufficient underlying facts to enable the to determine the nature and extent of the information or assistance requested and the return information to be disclosed to comply with taxpayer’s request. b. Conﬁrmed the identity of the taxpayer and the designee. c. Conﬁrmed the date, the nature and the extent of the information or tance requested. (

) The regulation also clariﬁes that the taxpayer can verbally approve IRS sures to someone accompanying the taxpayer at in-person meetings with IRS or participating in a phone conversation between the taxpayer and the IRS. (

) FOIA requests come to TE/GE from Privacy, Governmental Liaison & sure (PGLD). a. (06-16-2020) Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Requests

Generally, PGLD sends a copy of the TE/GE-related FOIA request to TE/GE FOIA coordinator in the TE/GE Commissioner’s office for proper tracking. The TE/GE FOIA coordinator then sends a copy of the FOIA request to the appropriate Functional FOIA POC, who sends a copy to the appropriate functional responder. Sometimes, PGLD may send a copy of a FOIA request directly to a TE/GE employee likely to have responsive documents. If you receive a FOIA request directly from PGLD, notify the TE/GE FOIA coordinator as provided for in IRM
Provide the TE/GE FOIA coordinator a copy the FOIA request received for proper tracking. Also, provide a copy of FOIA request to the ITG FOIA POC.
